comments.commentBody: It wasn't meant as a joke, since I was quoting a 2016 candidate.

Can we also talk about putting Steve Bannon in a permanent seat on the National Security Council, while removing the chair of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the head of National Intelligence. And spare me talk that his 7 years as an officer in the Navy is just as good as a 4 star general.

Will the Republican leadership find ANYTHING Trump does outrageous? Aren't they supposed to be the national security tough-guys? What is it Trump wants to do or is already doing he wants to keep hidden from the smart people?
Doesn't the NSC also run a secret panel with no records or oversight to put "American militants" on a capture / kill list?

Yes, I agree that that's one of the scarier things he's done so far, and calculated to coincide with the Immigration ban which has taken up most of the press and outrage. I have an incredibly bad feeling about all of this, and although I too was hoping that it couldn't happen in the U.S...

Any elected officials, Republican and Democrat, who don't start asking tough questions and putting on the brakes instead of licking Trump's boots will be complicit in any atrocities that follow.

Regarding Bannon's appointment. I believe this analysis of this weekend's news cycle is quite telling. And, given what we're seeing, pretty accurate.

https://medium.com/@yonatanzunger/trial-balloon-for-a-coup-e024990891d5#...

There are many kinds of bibingka but It is surprising to hear it described as an appetizer. It is usually eaten as a treat or a dessert, often with fresh coconut gratings and brown sugar. It is also topped with a runny caramel made of the coconut milk cooked with sugar, reduced to a soft ball stage and spread over fancy grade white rice cooked with coconut milk and water in a pot and flattened on a pan lined with banana leaves. Recipes are mostly unwritten and handed down in the kitchen not taught in a school. The best Filipino food is always very fresh and very varied. The use of lime, 'calamansi', and tamarind are a good part of its flavor.

Filipino cooking is inherently fusion, incorporating Chinese and Spanish cooking, many of its ingredients imported. Seven Up is a bit of a surprise - as a staple - sounds like Spam in Hawaii.

Writing this is making me hungry!

When I had breast reduction surgery about eight years ago the surgeon told me quite specifically that withe this procedure, 25% of patients lose sensation, 25% have better sensation and 50% would experience no change. I guess I'm grateful that I had a [woman] surgeon who made a point of stating this clearly in advance.

I wonder where this bit of misinformation originates. You hear it pretty frequently: taxes on corporations necessarily are ultimately paid by consumers.

Thing is, you won't learn this in any econ class; not even 101. One of the really basic "hey let's draw a graph of a market and calculate stuff" is tax incidence. And even at the most basic levels the case is crystal clear that consumers only carry the whole tax in rare circumstances. And that a lot of common setups in fact fall entirely or largely on shareholders.

And yet here we are; jp here clearly lacks any econ training whatsoever, but is just so certain he or she knows more about who will pay this tax than a Nobel economist. I suppose that's pretty much the sentiment that caused us to elect to the most powerful job in the world a man with no government experience, no knowledge of any area of policy, no interest in learning anything at all, and perhaps most important no respect for democracy, laws, norms or even decency.

Thanks for this thoughtful comment. Aside from the practical problem of accommodating the millions in need from the disastrous world situations in progress, which Germany tried to acknowledge and humanely respond to with mixed results, the more fortunate are unlikely to put their fortunes at risk beyond a variable threshold compounded of compassion and means and emotion. But the US threshold has been stingy, and that's an understatement. We are forgetting how to share.

It will be interesting to see if the chaos this unleashes makes the markets insecure tomorrow. That bubble at the casino on Wall Street is going to burst sooner or later, but a lot of the profiteers have already taken their money and run. Our looters and criminals are high end in this country, why worry about the poor and huddled masses of Ms. Liberty.
all you and the NYT can do is hope...
Nope.   The Donald is a kakistocract.
When the alternative is meritocracy, "uh, anything else, lets try kakistocracy".

Want to complain? Or win?

Swing voters choose primarily on economic issues. On every other major issue, each voter - and each party - already has fixed positions, which they simply won't change.

80% of voters favor protecting Social Security. 70% or more favor a higher minimum wage. So, why won't Democratic candidates *own* those positions, and win decisively? Because Democratic primary voters now hold traditionally Republican economic policy positions. They are elitist snobs who pretend to care about the working class, but really don't. They demonize anyone running on populist economics as a demagogue, and declare the broad prosperity of the New Deal as unrealistic and unattainable. They demonize any national leader espousing "nationalism" - as if it isn't their *job* to work for the good of the nation.

Trump is a symptom of a divided and disillusioned electorate that realizes any candidate approved by our establishment pols and media, by definition is not on their side. The establishment news media has made themselves irrelevant - a joke - like we used to view communist propaganda newspapers, such as Pravda. This leaves voters desperate enough to vote for a Trump, and totally unreachable. Calling them names is just going to make them stick their fingers deeper into their ears.

With his misguided policy move to ban Muslim entry into the US not only Trump has exposed the US to new security threats but also invited worldwide disapproval and protests which might lead to serious legal challenges to his ill-conceived and mischievous immigration policy and a retaliatory ban on the visits of Americans to the Muslim countries. Even he himself might face a similar situation whenever he plans official visit to these countries.

Suppose that in retaliation all Muslim majority nations put a ban on visits or immigration or refugees by all people from the Christian majority nations (US, UK, Canada, Australia, Germany, France, etc.), apart from of course Muslims who are "discriminated" against in these nations as a minority.
It would be the exact mirror of what Trump has just done.
Think about it.

My husband noticed the same difference (in the pervasive stench of urine) between his mother's 1990s nursing home and his dad's 2000s nursing home. Nursing aides confided what has made most of the difference: adult diapers. This has certainly reduced the odor problem and the tedious work of changing wet/soiled bedding, but if diapers go unchanged, it's still a health problem for the resident.

My sister once looked into taking our father in (for hospice care) and hiring home health aides. She made some inquiries -- in the major metropolitan area of Seattle -- and was essentially told "Good luck finding anyone." And at the going rate (which they earn!), anyone you'd find would be prohibitively expensive for 24-hour care, meaning family members would provide unpaid care for much of the 24 hours.

One challenge with providing in-home care is having an elder-appropriate home. Fall prevention is critical. Even a ranch home may have a step up or down to navigate around an entry, and many bathrooms have been long designed to minimize space, rather than the room needed to provide assistance or structural supports such as grab bars. More effort is needed to make universal design features such as larger doorways, easy to grab knobs standard features.

Why is this article illustrated with a cartoonish depiction of an elderly lady, tiny useless hands, helpless-looking, feet unable to touch the floor, looking upward for salvation?  Be careful: the ways in which you caricature the elderly have an effect on society and institutions, and give signals.  This cartoon seems to sanction the dismissal of older human beings.

Ebmem, gh made it clear in his comment that some people are not well cared for at home.  Depending on the family resources and the level of disability, it is sometimes very difficult to care for some one with high needs properly at home.

As a former RN supervisor:  you are wrong.  The care is horrible and when you report a problem to the Director of Nursing you become the problem yourself.  There are many unexplained deaths that the facility lies about and the family is helpless due to arbitration clauses in agreements signed upon entry.

Assigning a letter grade reduces the analysis to a meaningless data point. Within a single facility, one patient may have excellent care and one may have dismal care. Determinants include the systemic functions of the facility, but also the individual dispositions of a particular resident, the particular staff assigned to that resident, and the attending physician. Also the resources and medication therapy may be influenced by the insurance carrier for that individual resident. The relationship of the family members and the staff can highly influence the care received, ranging from mutual respect to constant conflict.

Finally, much of the regulatory framework is not necessarily helpful, and often regulators value paper compliance above actual care delivered, and their intervention may actually divert good caregivers from delivery of care to completion of forms.

Ultimately, the complexity of care given to the frail resident matches the complexity of varied styles of living. Trying to force the entire care structure into the medical care system, increases cost, increases liability concerns, decreases individual choices, and ultimately separates the resident from their natural social contacts. The formality of this high tech care is often used as a salve for the guilty consciences of the family.

you make a lot of good observations; it is a very complex and difficult problem; we know whats bad, we know how difficult it is to provide appropriate care under the best of circustances; how do we move towards something better?

For what it is worth: I work in two nursing homes in rural upstate New York as a Hospice volunteer and I am overwhelmed how good they are - perfect, no; very good, YES! It can be done. How do we get more to do it right?

Hindu, here.

This article is WRONG.

I moved to a Christian country. I repeat, I moved to a Christian country. It isn't my place to start whining that my Hindu culture isn't being accommodated. I left India, remember?

In India, a prominent politician tried to ban non-Indian (i.e., White) women from starring in Bollywood movies. That's India for you. It isn't the shining example of acceptance people make it out to be.

Mr. Blow, much, much worse than the Trump-Bannon pickaxe that is digging up America's front lawn is the silence in Congress. The same Congress that threw up roadblocks every day of Barack Obama's presidency.

House Speaker Paul Ryan defended his president's "executive overreach" in direct contradiction to what he said in December 2015 on then-candidate Donald Trump's proposed temporary ban on Muslims entering the United States: "This is not conservatism." Why the quick switch, Mr. Speaker?

Mitch McConnell, who opposed every day of Barack Obama's presidency, suddenly found a voice on ABC News: "Look, the president has a lot of latitude to try to secure the country." He wasn't as generous with his "latitude" between 2009-2017; one wonders why.

The new president, as this space has complained since the inauguration, is merely the rubber-stamp for Stephen Bannon. This attempted exclusion of refugees from nations with majority-Muslim origins is no accident. Nor is the Trump hard line about his Mexican wall or his threats to turn the streets of Chicago into, yes, "a war zone", by flooding the city with an armed National Guard. Would he, like Richard Daley in 1968, order them to "shoot to kill?"

What this president desires is anarchy and chaos and having achieved disorder, the next step is martial law. Citizen appeals to the SCOTUS for relief? With John Roberts, Samuel Alito, Clarence Thomas wearing the black robes of refined and genteel terror?

I hear something ticking.

"Bad actor nations?" Then where are Saudi Arabia (18 of the 19 9/11 hijackers plus Osama Bin Laden) and Egypt (Bin Laden's assistant)?
Amazingly, NONE of the countries on the ban list have had a citizen responsible for even a single terrorism death in the US, @TBS. The problem is that the actual "bad actor" nations have monetary links to the Trump Organization and are consumers of our military industrial complex' output.
Yes. A "Trumped-up," fake terrorist attack on the homeland and martial law. It could definitely happen. Forewarned is forearmed. But, how to prepare?

I could not agree more. The hour is upon us, already. Congress seems to be hoping that it's going to get better automagically, but that's not going to happen. They are the only body with the true authority to call this out. Is this 25th Amendment territory, or will it require impeachment? How many people have to show up at the Capitol before Congress "gets it?"

Nothing in his DNA and lengthy record as a boarder line criminal and delusional megalomaniac business tycoon provides a glimmer of hope that an international disaster is not in our nation's immediate future.   Our only hope resides with what remains of the handful of sane  Republican establishment types, who must now be all but certain  that they will have to take courageous  action against their president. A rising tide of large, frequent demonstrations and great fear among the those few Republicans  who retain some semblance of moral leadership are our only glimmer of light against the gathering storm clouds and menacing darkness.

Mr. Trump's biggest mistake is signing executive orders over the weekend which allows for demonstrations, spontaneous or otherwise.
He should be advised by whatever staff he has in place that he should rein in his workaholic nature, narcissistic or not, and enjoy his weekends, or at least wait until the workweek begins to sign orders. Play golf Mr. Trump or play with the grandchildren over the weekend.
The American people have to go back to work on Monday and most will be at the job and be too busy to "fight for American values" when they are at work, except of course for the American value of working.
What a completely banal comment. Wait and see.
This is what you're hoping for... "too busy to "fight for American values"?

To Ira,

I do not hope for anything. Rather I simply wish to describe a situation as I see it.
People punching time clocks rarely have time to demonstrate during the week.

The most important thing for Trump supporters to understand is: you're next.

As soon as Trump finishes toying with the majority, he will turn on his supporters. This is what malignant narcissists do - idealize, devalue and discard.

The only way to stop it is to start impeachment proceedings. Calmly and firmly.

This is a bi-partisan task.
@Terri: You had me until "impeachment." Pence is worse.
THIS.
Impeachment is indeed a bipartisan task; we'd have a better chance of achieving it if we asked Santa Claus.

Absolutely protest and demand justice! But, don't get distracted. Demand that Congress subpoena the tax returns so his indebtedness to Putin is exposed and he is impeached. Everything else he's doing, no matter how vile, is a calculated move designed to keep the focus away from this most basic flaw... that we have a puppet of a hostile foreign government sitting in our highest office. He must be removed!
Thank you for this. You are dead on - focus, focus, focus.

Please keep in mind Congress is controlled by the republicans, who are gleefully on board with the coup. People really gotta stop thinking that they will be going anything to stop him. No tax returns will be subpoenaed, no impeachment will take place. Congress will function as the illegitimate autocrat allows and requires. Ryan and McConnell clearly understand this, they are no longer a check or balance or even a separate branch of government.

ed connor, all we Liberals really need to impeach Trump is a good look at his taxes for 2015.  Well, that and for Trump to keep up the shooting himself in the foot thing.  When the Republican House sees the numbers of Americans out in the streets protesting, protesting, protesting and finally realize that even their own so-called base is also protesting they will move.  They will have to or else they will lose everything in 2018.  Of course, the way things are going so far in only week 2, the Republicans are going to lose pretty much everything anyway.

The president is playing to his red, racist and rabid base by fulfilling his campaign promises to make America great again. Everything he's done since being sworn in has produced outrage and incredulity. He's thumbed his nose at convention and with his Muslim ban has now violated the Constitution by targeting a specific religion, Islam, and its worshipers, as unwelcome and undesirable in the United States.

Speaker Paul Ryan, he of the day-long smirk during the Inauguration ceremonies, watched America change its colors and turn its back on everything the republic stood for since 1620. The Republicans pilloried President Obama for executive overreach and deemed his actions unconstitutional but have been silent on the excesses of this president. The GOP most certainly has this president's back.

Mr. Blow, you say that America will not stand for authoritarian abuse of power by a president and you are right, but but this is exactly what the country voted for in November. The angry red tide that washed this great white shark into the Oval Office may be happy now but soon they'll realize that we as a country are going to need a bigger boat.

Trump, like Quint, has jumped the shark.
The ban and the reactions to it are just the first wave in a series of salvos ready to be fired by Deathstar Trump, but inside it looks more like "Spaceballs" than "Starwars". This isn't, however, an laughing matter. Trump's moves on the NSC should scare the bejesus out of even the hardest line atheists. A self professed far right neo-nazi replaces the head of intelligence and the head of our joint military? I used to think Don Rumsfeld was as bad as they got, but now I see he only wanted to get into 2 wars at the same time. A cabinet of plutocrats, many of whom seem to actually be from Pluto, each one more of a bad fit for the job than the next. Executive orders that defy legal analysis since they haven't been vetted by actual lawyers, throwing the nation into chaos and nearly freezing our transportation system in one swell foop. An incurious, overbearing, cackling maniac tweeting through half the night about TV shows and actors in the voice of a hurt 12 year old, albeit one whose finger is on the big, shiny red button. A putative right wing robot second in line and a near clone of him in 3rd position. But none of that matters, because Bannon, through Trump, will bring us into martial law and eventual fascist dictatorship, and democracy will not-so-slowly disintegrate as the lawyers and courts parse the various edicts as their effects take hold, and their analyses and decisions will come too late, if at all. And you thought W was bad.

@ soxared, 04-07-13
@Patrick - actually, it would be poetic justice if the president shares the same fate as Quint in the movie, slipping and sliding in the chum he himself created as he beckoned forth the great white monster to his boat. In Quint's USS Indianapolis monologue, he foretold of his own fate that would happen very shortly.

It's what 27% of the eligible American electorate voted for. Without the pernicious effects of voter suppression, we might have had someone who sends emails rather than tweets. Hardly a bit of difference, right?
Thank you, Mr. Blow, for voicing our concerns so succinctly.  I wish more writers at the Times had your backbone.
